kpis.name: Statute of Limitations Remaining
kpis.definition: The average number of months remaining before the legal right to pursue unpaid accounts expires, based on the governing state's debt collection laws.
kpis.why_it_matters: This KPI determines whether the portfolio is legally collectible. Once the statute of limitations expires, a debt buyer can no longer pursue collection through legal means, significantly reducing portfolio value. Tracking this ensures only legally viable accounts are priced and sold.
kpis.data_source: State Attorney General or Consumer Finance databases; Hospital legal department summaries

scoring_rules.description: Excellent — strong legal window for recovery
Moderate — half of the legal window remains
Poor — approaching or past legal expiration

kpis.name: Average Debt Age
kpis.definition: The average number of days that unpaid patient accounts have been outstanding since the date of service or billing.
kpis.why_it_matters: Debt age is one of the strongest predictors of collectability. The older a debt is, the less likely it is to be recovered. Measuring this KPI allows both hospitals and buyers to assess the freshness and overall quality of the portfolio.
kpis.data_source: Hospital billing system (A/R aging report), CMS Cost Reports

scoring_rules.description: Excellent — debt is fresh and highly collectible
Poor — aged debt, low recovery potential

kpis.name: Recovery Rate
kpis.definition: Percentage of total patient receivables historically recovered by the hospital within 12 months.
kpis.why_it_matters: A high recovery rate indicates strong billing practices and efficient follow-up, reducing buyer risk. A low recovery rate suggests weak collection operations and lower likelihood of repayment.
kpis.data_source: Hospital billing reports, CMS Cost Reports, or financial statements (IRS 990)
